body:
### Neovim version (nvim -v)

v0.9.0-dev-447+g6c285a6e49 (Also experienced crashes with v0.8, but may be different cause)

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, this function is nvim-only I think

### Operating system/version

ArchLinux

### Terminal name/version

konsole

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

Arch neovim-git (also experience crashes with official neovim v0.8 package)

### How to reproduce the issue

Not exactly sure how to repro. I've been experiencing neovim crashes lately. I don't know exactly what triggers it, but some file types (typescript and markdown) seem to trigger it more often than others. Sometimes it crashes soon after opening many times in a row, sometimes I can go many days between crashes. It seems to happen most often when saving, but sometimes it happens just when moving the cursor around.

I typically use neovim-gtk, but recently tried running plain neovim in a terminal to see if that helped. It still crashes, but now I get a helpful message out (although it leaves my terminal in a trashed state). 

```
nvim: /home/mstearn/.cache/yay/neovim-git/src/neovim-git/src/nvim/rbuffer.c:168: rbuffer_consumed_compact: Assertion `(size_t)(buf->read_ptr - buf->write_ptr) == buf->size' failed.
zsh: IOT instruction  nvim
```

The failing assert is on [this line](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4b02291f81b76eda029d4eae1c1d59c1a946a032/src/nvim/rbuffer.c#L168). That function is only called from [one place](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4b02291f81b76eda029d4eae1c1d59c1a946a032/src/nvim/msgpack_rpc/channel.c#L238), and both were introduced in [this commit](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/d5f047bee04a42f40425c34061c84b39af846e1f). While I don't have a repro, I am hoping that something near one of those lines will jump out at someone who knows this code (possibly @bfredl who committed it) as obviously incorrect.

### Expected behavior

I'd really like my editor not to crash :)

### Actual behavior

neovim crashes

comment_data.body:
Had a similar issue. Arch linux user as well downloading neovim nightly. My build script is as follows:
```
#!/bin/bash
cd ~
sudo rm -r neovim
git clone https://github.com/neovim/neovim
cd neovim
sudo make CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo
sudo make install
cd ../
sudo rm -r neovim
```
Error is:
`rbuffer.c:144: rbuffer_consumed: Assertion count && count <= buf->size' failed..`

However it works when downloading the tarball here https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/tag/nightly

I have the same issue on macOs, after building it myself and with downloading the tarball.
The error is:
`Assertion failed: ((size_t)(buf->read_ptr - buf->write_ptr) == buf->size), function rbuffer_consumed_compact, file rbuffer.c, line 168.`
It seems to be triggered by a changed made between 4703e56 and c590641 but I cannot say more, I might try later to find the specific commit where this begins

There are two different assertions mentioned here.
- ``rbuffer.c:144: rbuffer_consumed: Assertion count && count <= buf->size' failed`` can be simply triggered by `echo | nvim --clean --embed`, but `rbuffer_consumed` is used in many places.
- ``rbuffer.c:168: rbuffer_consumed_compact: Assertion `(size_t)(buf->read_ptr - buf->write_ptr) == buf->size' failed`` is the one first mentioned in the issue, and `rbuffer_consumed_compact` is only used in one place.
I've had both but I do not know what triggers one or the other, the `rbuffer.c:144` was triggered more often tho

I get the ` rbuffer.c:144: rbuffer_consumed: Assertion count && count <= buf->size' failed..` one when deleting multiple lines at a time with something like `4dd` but not when I do one line at a time. Log shows:
```
ERR 2023-01-03T17:18:45.445 ?.139615   chan_close_with_error:573: RPC: failed to decode msgpack
```
lsp log shows:
```
[ERROR][2023-01-03 17:23:00] .../vim/lsp/rpc.lua:734	"rpc"	"terraform-ls"	"stderr"	'2023/01/03 17:23:00 rpc_logger.go:45: Error for "textDocument/semanticTokens/full" (ID 2): [-32800] error code -32800: %!s(<nil>)\n2023/01/03 17:23:00 opts.go:205: Completed 1 requests [3.908631032s elapsed]\n'
```

FYI I was editing a terraform file and have the terraform treesitter module loaded and highlight enabled and terraformls lsp server.

I also do not get this behavior with 0.8.2, only with nightly.

It's highly reproducible for me with the `telescope.nvim` plugin on Mac. If I do a live grep and type 3-4 letters quickly or do backspaces in the prompt then it crashes rapidly. If I type each letter with a pause, then it's ok. ~~No crashes with the nightly tarball~~. I just installed the nightly tarball again and it crashes the same way now.
Unless anyone can provide more useful information, can anyone else that experiences this just provide a 👍 reaction to the OP so we can gauge who this affects.

I think the likely culprits of this could be 6ba34e21fee2a81677e8261dfeaf24c8cd320500 (since it's LSP related which I think is the only user of `rbuffer_consumed_compact`) or cce736218f465511194465410e1ba23b5530e46f (since this was quite a big change).

I have a backtrace. No idea if it's useful or not:

```
Thread 0 Crashed::  Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread
0   libsystem_kernel.dylib        	       0x19ac4e1b0 __pthread_kill + 8
1   libsystem_pthread.dylib       	       0x19ac84cec pthread_kill + 288
2   libsystem_c.dylib             	       0x19abbe2c8 abort + 180
3   libsystem_c.dylib             	       0x19abbd620 __assert_rtn + 272
4   nvim                          	       0x100448790 rbuffer_consumed_compact + 284
5   nvim                          	       0x1003d46a8 receive_msgpack + 344
6   nvim                          	       0x1002ddd68 read_cb + 340
7   nvim                          	       0x10011e470 uv__read + 328 (stream.c:1158) [inlined]
8   nvim                          	       0x10011e470 uv__stream_io + 768 (stream.c:1226)
9   nvim                          	       0x100123bd8 uv__io_poll + 1000 (kqueue.c:378)
10  nvim                          	       0x10011538c uv_run + 384 (core.c:406)
11  nvim                          	       0x1002db688 loop_poll_events + 284
12  nvim                          	       0x10051db64 ui_client_run + 1052
13  nvim                          	       0x1003865c8 main + 16272
14  dyld                          	       0x19a95be50 start + 2544
```

After #18375 simply this can cause this assert failure:
```vim
:lua io.stdout:write('a')
```

This issue was created before #18375 was merged though.
yes, stdin/stdout fd:s will need to be renamed in the server. I'll look into a fix.

> After #18375 simply this can cause this assert failure:
> 
> ```viml
> :lua io.stdout:write('a')
> ```
> 
> This issue was created before #18375 was merged though.

I can confirm that this reproduces the error, after typing this command on a buffer, NeoVim crashes.
This `assert((size_t)(buf->read_ptr - buf->write_ptr) == buf->size);` doesn't seem to make any sense. It can fail whenever `buf->size != 0`, or `count < buf->size` when this function is called.

This assert failure can happen with the following sequence:
1. `rbuffer_produced()` is called with a `count` of 65536, then the buffer is full (`buf->size == 65536`) and `buf->read_ptr` and `buf->write_ptr` are both set to `buf->start_ptr`.
2. 65533 bytes are parsed as msgpack, so `rbuffer_consumed_compact()` is called with a `count` of 65533.
3. After consuming 65533 bytes, `buf->read_ptr == buf->start_ptr + 65533` and `buf->size == 3`, while `buf->write_ptr == 0`
4. Assert failure
However, when rbuffer isn't full, `buf->write_ptr == buf->read_ptr + buf->size`, so this assertion fails whenever `buf->size != 0`.

Not sure if related, but with #21675 applied I'm now getting a different crash but In the same area of the code:

```
nvim(25902,0x1f5feba80) malloc: *** error for object 0x117814440: pointer being freed was not allocated
```

```
Thread 0 Crashed::  Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread
0   libsystem_kernel.dylib        	       0x19ac4e1b0 __pthread_kill + 8
1   libsystem_pthread.dylib       	       0x19ac84cec pthread_kill + 288
2   libsystem_c.dylib             	       0x19abbe2c8 abort + 180
3   libsystem_malloc.dylib        	       0x19aadcb1c malloc_vreport + 908
4   libsystem_malloc.dylib        	       0x19aae0330 malloc_report + 64
5   libsystem_malloc.dylib        	       0x19aaece60 find_zone_and_free + 308
6   nvim                          	       0x1046864c0 rpc_send_event + 660
7   nvim                          	       0x1047bc2c0 tinput_flush + 480
8   nvim                          	       0x1047bb3c8 tinput_read_cb + 156
9   nvim                          	       0x104599bd0 read_cb + 340
10  nvim                          	       0x1043da4a0 uv__read + 328 (stream.c:1158) [inlined]
11  nvim                          	       0x1043da4a0 uv__stream_io + 768 (stream.c:1226)
12  nvim                          	       0x1043dfc08 uv__io_poll + 1000 (kqueue.c:378)
13  nvim                          	       0x1043d13bc uv_run + 384 (core.c:406)
14  nvim                          	       0x1045974c4 loop_poll_events + 284
15  nvim                          	       0x1047cf2c0 ui_client_run + 760
16  nvim                          	       0x104638708 main + 16496
17  dyld                          	       0x19a95be50 start + 2544
```

I have been getting this a lot lately. Any debugging steps I can do to help resolve this?

My neovim version:
```
❯ nvim --version
NVIM v0.9.0-dev
Build type: RelWithDebInfo
LuaJIT 2.1.0-beta3
Compilation: /usr/bin/cc -g -O2 -fdebug-prefix-map=/build/neovim-Se7AhW/neovim-0.9.0~ubuntu1+git202301110019-15ee93c0b-333b5866f=. -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security -U_FORTIFY_SOURCE -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=1 -O2 -g  -Og -g -Wall -Wextra -pedantic -Wno-unused-parameter -Wstrict-prototypes -std=gnu99 -Wshadow -Wconversion -Wdouble-promotion -Wmissing-noreturn -Wmissing-format-attribute -Wmissing-prototypes -Wimplicit-fallthrough -Wvla -fno-common -fdiagnostics-color=auto -fstack-protector-strong -DNVIM_UNIBI_HAS_VAR_FROM -DNVIM_MSGPACK_HAS_FLOAT32 -DNVIM_TS_HAS_SET_MATCH_LIMIT -DNVIM_TS_HAS_SET_ALLOCATOR -DINCLUDE_GENERATED_DECLARATIONS -D_GNU_SOURCE -DMIN_LOG_LEVEL=3 -I/build/neovim-Se7AhW/neovim-0.9.0~ubuntu1+git202301110019-15ee93c0b-333b5866f/.deps/usr/include -I/usr/include -I/usr/include/luajit-2.1 -I/build/neovim-Se7AhW/neovim-0.9.0~ubuntu1+git202301110019-15ee93c0b-333b5866f/build/src/nvim/auto -I/build/neovim-Se7AhW/neovim-0.9.0~ubuntu1+git202301110019-15ee93c0b-333b5866f/build/include -I/build/neovim-Se7AhW/neovim-0.9.0~ubuntu1+git202301110019-15ee93c0b-333b5866f/build/cmake.config -I/build/neovim-Se7AhW/neovim-0.9.0~ubuntu1+git202301110019-15ee93c0b-333b5866f/src
Compiled by buildd@lcy02-amd64-001

Features: +acl +iconv +tui
See ":help feature-compile"

   system vimrc file: "$VIM/sysinit.vim"
  fall-back for $VIM: "/usr/share/nvim"

Run :checkhealth for more info
```

> This assert failure can happen with the following sequence:
> 
>     1. `rbuffer_produced()` is called with a `count` of 65536, then the buffer is full (`buf->size == 65536`) and `buf->read_ptr` and `buf->write_ptr` are both set to `buf->start_ptr`.
> 
>     2. 65533 bytes are parsed as msgpack, so `rbuffer_consumed_compact()` is called with a `count` of 65533.
> 
>     3. After consuming 65533 bytes, `buf->read_ptr == buf->start_ptr + 65533` and `buf->size == 3`, while `buf->write_ptr == 0`
> 
>     4. Assert failure

This was the case I found out using `rr` when I last got a crash with steps similar to the one mentioned in #21785.

Ok, rbuffer needs to be refactored to actually behave like a ring buffer. As a quickfix, the only exception that could happen in msgpack code is when buffer is exactly full, which could be added to the assert.
#21899 may fix some `rbuffer.c:144: rbuffer_consumed: Assertion count && count <= buf->size' failed` crashes.

Thanks for the fix @zeertzjq - I've updated to nightly and searching with telescope doesn't crash for me now. Previous nightly it would crash quite quickly,   

_edit : before fix it would crash with telescope search when I entered characters quickly into the search box, on MacOS._

Not sure if this helps, but based on a number of user reports and by my own testing, it seems this issue only occurs on Macos. I can not reproduce this on Windows. The issue seems to be triggered by scrolling quickly in a buffer.

The repro is unfortunately not that minimal: https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim/issues/315#issuecomment-1386650267

To reproduce, open with `-u` and a large file, like `neovim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua`

Then scroll fast with the mouse or touchpad while the LSP is loading the project.

On Macos it crashes within 2 seconds.

On Linux it never crashes.

@folke I saw this on Ubuntu and Arch Linux as well

Edit: not with noice though.. The notification was truncated so didn't see the full message

@FredeEB with Noice? For Noice, this has been fixed in Noice and will be fixed upstream. But that was related to `vim.ui_attach`. There seems to be another issue that's not related to `vim.ui_attach` as well. And for me at least that issue only triggers on Macos

I think there were a few vectors that could trip this and we've fixed quite a few of them. So when reporting on this, make sure it is for the latest commit on master.

I haven't had this trip on me for a while now on MacOS, and I was getting it a lot before.
I haven't seen this for a full 2 days now so going to add the "needs response" label.
ok, cool. Will test myself tomorrow on macos
Closing as this is likely fixed.
Yep, the noice issue is also resolved. Thank you all!

I just left a comment in #22199.

TL;DR 
Did a bisect from 0.7.2 and our crashes starts with commit d5f047bee04a42f40425c34061c84b39af846e1f
I am on MacOs with latest MacOs, latest Alcritty terminal, latest NeoVim. The behavior that OP reported is happening for me now. It happens when either scrolling with mouse or ctrl-d and ctrl-u

labels.description: We need minimal steps to reproduce the issue
labels.name: needs:repro

labels.description: issue reporting a crash or segfault
labels.name: bug-crash

labels.description: wrong behavior that was introduced in a previous commit (please bisect)
labels.name: bug-regression

title: Assertion in `rbuffer_consumed_compact` tripped
